ENGLISH: Con la guerra e con la diplomazia è stata creata un'unione araba. Dovremmo unirci?
FRENCH: Grâce aux armes et à la diplomatie, une union arabe a été constituée. Devons-nous la rejoindre ?
GERMAN: Durch Krieg und Diplomatie wurde eine arabische Union gegründet. Sollen wir ihr beitreten?

ENGLISH: Forma l'Arabia
Certo!
Mai!

Ci sono disordini tra gli ufficiali nelle forze armate, abbastanza che alcuni di loro stanno diffondendo attivamente dissenso tra le file. Il nostro paese sarebbe migliore, dicono, se l'esercito fosse in carica piuttosto che il governo attuale, potrà essere eletto, ma secondo loro si è dimostrato troppo inefficace. E sembra che molti sotto il loro comando siano d'accordo.
Colpo di Stato?
Questo porterà a problemi in futuro.

Le nostre forze armate a $CAPITAL$ hanno raggiunto gli edifici governativi: non per svolgere il loro dovere di protezione del governo, ma invece per deporre i nostri leader e per diventare i nostri nuovi governanti. Affermano che il nostro paese sia in uno stato di "sollevazione" e che solo l'esercito possa ripristinare l'ordine.
Colpo di Stato Militare
D'ora in poi ci governerà l'esercito
Ci opporremo al governo militare!

C'è un gran combattere per le strade di Parigi mentre l'esercito $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ avanza per catturare la città. L'artiglieria è spostata alla Collina di Chaillot, dopo delle barricate improvvisate mentre la fanteria scappa dal 7º arrondissement e si muove sistematicamente di casa in casa, di quartiere in quartiere, combattendo una battaglia contro irregolari armati. L'Arco di Trionfo è demolito dai pionieri mentre l'artiglieria sulla collina mira verso la Torre Eiffel. Per molti minuti la città è assordata dal tuonare dell'artiglieria finché non cala il silenzio e l'unico suono è la stridere del metallo, che lentamente crolla. I soldati nemici urlano eccitati mentre guardano la Torre Eiffel piegarsi e cadere nella Senna, ormai ridotta ad un blocco amorfo di metallo. \n \nIl fuoco imperversa fuori controllo nelle parti orientali della città, illuminando la città mentre i combattimenti continuano nella notte.
Distruzione della Torre Eiffel
Un giorno mesto per il nostro paese.

Scattered gunfire can be heard echoing through the empty streets of London as the last pockets of resistance to the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ occupation are quelled. The parliament houses in the Palace of Westminster lay empty while $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ soldiers run up and down placing explosives in the silent corridors. A $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ general silently read the orders that came from the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ capital with instructions to destroy the Palace in an attempt to crush the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ spirit. The explosives are detonated at the same time as the Clock Tower bell strike its precise hourly strike. The tower is engulfed by flames as parts of the western palace collapse, with pieces of the Big Ben landing on the Thames along with other debris while nearby buildings are hit by flaming debris and catch fire. $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ soldiers watch and cherish from a safe distance as the glass that once contained the phrase ‘DOMINE SALVAM FAC REGINAM NOSTRAM VICTORIAM PRIMAM’ rains on the ground. Nearby, $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ soldiers storm the Buckingham Palace just to find out that the $MONARCHTITLE$ has already fled the country. They hoist the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ flag and turn to see the smoke rising in the horizon. London is lost.
The Fall of the Palace of Westminster
Sell Fort Ross to the Mexican citizen John Sutter?
Fort Ross Purchase?
We gladly accept.
We refuse.
$FROMCOUNTRY$ has agreed to sell the Fort Ross trading post to us! Long live $COUNTRY$!
$FROMCOUNTRY$ Accepts!
Excellent.
$MONARCHTITLE$, negotiations with $FROMCOUNTRY$ over Fort Ross have stalled, and they have declined to sell us the colony.
$FROMCOUNTRY$ Declines!
Hm, I see.

I saw, about four miles to the left, a sheet of water, which ultimately proved to be a creek and the southernmost part of what the Arabs call the Ukerewe Sea. Convinced that I finally found the source of the Nile, I went down a grassy and jungled depression into a deep, dirty, viscid nullah, which communicated with the southern end of the creek, which we named Jordan. As we followed the creek, that increased in breadth as it extended northwards, we saw many little islands in Ukerewe, well wooded, standing boldly out of the water. The journey continued through another tortuous day until we reached the village of Isamiro, where the view was clearer and better. In the distant horizon a calm sea line started to appear between north and west. Even in a well-known country the view would have attracted attention for its placid beauty, he thought to himself. He felt he had solved the great old riddle.
The Source of the Nile Discovered?
We shall name it…
Perhaps it should be called…
Our $MONARCHTITLE$ would be satisfied with the name…
This great body of water will be known as…
We need a name worthy of its beauty…

One of our explorers found a massive body of water in Africa, and he claims that it's the true source of the Nile! Upon preliminary reports, it seems that what was found is a huge lake that might as well be the source of the Nile. He insists we should call this discovery Lake Victoria.
Oh well.

The factories extend their flanks of fouler brick one after another, bare, with shutter-less windows, like economical and colossal prisons… and inside, lit by gas-jets and deafened by the uproar of their own labour, toil thousands of workmen, penned in, regimented, hands active, feet motionless, all day and every day, mechanically serving their machines…’ \n The hard work that the city’s workers perform has outraged many, and a committee has been formed to tackle the rough working conditions.
Long Work Hours
We should consider legislation to change this.
Hard work is the foundation of a good moral character.
